shu: raw returns some magic object that tells json.stringify to use the string as source instead of a string
content.formatted_body: shu: raw returns some magic object that tells json.stringify to use the string as source instead of a string

content.body: In the cases where I have needed position information in JSON, I've generally had to rely on something like the TypeScript parser and AST, even in a purely JS project. My use cases so far have been fairly niche, such as doing minor updates to an existing JSON file while preserving the source formatting (usually for JSON files intended to be both human and machine readable such as package.json).
syg: right now, JSON.stringify of an object without a `toString` is guaranteed to do the thing you expect absent a reviver, but if the symbol is shared that's no longer true
content.formatted_body: syg: right now, JSON.stringify of an object without a toString is guaranteed to do the thing you expect absent a reviver, but if the symbol is shared that's no longer true

content.body: Michael Ficarra: I am strongly opposed to having the marker be an object with a symbol here because it implies that the engine will need to do a lookup on every object
content.formatted_body: Michael Ficarra: I am strongly opposed to having the marker be an object with a symbol here because it implies that the engine will need to do a lookup on every object

content.body: which is observable

it's simpler in the sense of "fewer kinds of object in the language", true, but not in terms of "how much observable behavior there is", and the second thing seems like the thing we should be minimizing most of the time
bakkot: fair point
that's a good point
though i don't think a particular problem for performance in the common case
